Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Tool to estimate object visibility to fish in complex aquatic environments.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop tools that will create vast amounts of water quality data for the nation's inland, fresh waters. The data allow for direct environmental monitoring and for validation of other remote sensing GIS techniques to measure inland water quality. Algorithms will also be developed to use the data to allow anglers to customize their selection of lures based on the time and location where they are fishing. The difficulty for the angler is anticipating which lures are most visible to the fish, because fish see differently than humans. This project develops software tools and water quality sensors that allow anglers to customize their fishing strategies for any type of water. The product will ultimately recommend lures that work well for a given location based on the properties of the water, the properties of the lures, and the visual capabilities of fish in that environment.

The proposed project will measure the optical properties of (a) lakes and rivers. First-generation photometers would be constructed to estimate the sub-surface transmission and light-levels at three wavelengths and capture relevant water quality data. The project also proposes new methods to accommodate the selection of fluorescent pigments on lures. Algorithms will use the data to estimate the visual contrasts as perceived by certain species of fish and determine which lures have the highest probability of success for that species - bass in the first instance. The novelty of this approach is that it relies on estimating critical lighting parameters at three wavelength bands. Traditional methods rely on spectrometers that estimate spectra with thousands of data points and are not feasible for anglers. This project directly tests whether 3 well-spaced data points can accurately estimate lighting environments, visual signals, and their transmission in diverse water bodies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of recreational fishing is simple - trick a fish to bite a lure so that it can be caught. Yet actually succeeding in this task is surprisingly difficult. BassInSight, Inc. develops technology whose mission is to help anglers customize their tackle (i.e., lure selection) based on water conditions (e.g., cloud cover, time of day, turbidity, algae etc.).  

BassInSight, Inc was awarded NSF-SBIR grant 1914319 in August of 2019. This outcome report outlines results stemming from the two primary project goals: (1) to expand the capabilities of our proprietary algorithms to predict lure visibility to largemouth bass as a function of lure optical properties and the inherent optical properties of the water and (2) to develop a low cost deployable light sensor to measure those inherent optical properties in the field. 

During the Phase I award period, BassInSight has conducted extensive data collection. Image collection was completed  in multiple stages, locations and environments. Fishing lures of varying types, sizes, colors, styles were purchased and organized into a standardized imagery library. In total, some 50+ lures were photographed under standardized environments in our photobooth and in outdoor mesocosms with varying water conditions. Our image library contains 1000+ images reflecting combinations of individual lights, colors, and frequency ranges (UV/Visible range of light). The imagery library of lures included color standards allowing for inclusion in comparative lighting analysis.

BassInSight’s core technology are algorithms that allow humans to perceive lures underwater through the bass visual system. The algorithms use image analysis to estimate the reflectance of lures at each pixel and combine these values with the predicted side-welling irradiance at a given depth, the attenuation of light, and the distance at which an object is viewed.  This allows for a calculation of the amount of light from the lure and from the background that reaches the bass eye. The new imaging techniques developed additional capabilities that take into account the nature of fluorescent paints, which are commonly used on lures. With these techniques, more accurate images of lures as perceived by the bass can be generated, which is an expansion of capabilities from previous iterations of our algorithms. These techniques allow for an estimation of the maximum viewing distance for a given lure, time, and place. 

This project also developed a prototype sensor that could evaluate the light environment and eventually utilize light attenuation to evaluate water quality shared with the mobile app. Sensor users would provide a dispersed network of independent data evaluations relayed back for environment and ecosystem monitoring. The first stage is producing a prototype that can determine light intensity and red/green/blue light composition in multiple directions. During the grant period, the project proceeded through two generations of development to produce a sensor capable of determining the lighting environment. Benchtop testing of the sensor shows promise as an improvable platform for future iteration toward a consumer product. The sensor is able to measure the lighting environment above, below and laterally. This model also has a detection channel where 5 color combinations of LED light are passed across a fixed distance of water. The detection channel LED/photodiode receptors will eventually be upgraded to a more sophisticated system, but initial testing shows promise.  In summary, this project developed and tested new methodology for the assessment of lure optical properties, new algorithms to evaluate those properties and predict visibility in different water conditions, and a new sensor to measure those water conditions. 

This project supported a diverse group of interns who worked on both algorithm and sensory development. If successful, this project will have the ability to not only provide data on water clarity to anglers but to also inform policy makers on water quality throughout the nation. These latter goals depend on field testing and user adoption.
